title: 112_s3084
content: The Act may be cited as the "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" and pertains to the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Title 38 of the United States Code to establish 12 geographically defined Veterans Integrated Service Networks, ensuring alignment with the Department's mission and implementation of national goals within each network. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network implements national goals and maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations and managing a regional budget. The Secretary oversees the regional budget and management of healthcare activities in the Veterans Health Administration within the Network, ensuring high-quality clinical programs and services are provided. The Secretary ensures effective, efficient, and safe delivery of highly satisfactory healthcare to patients and families. This includes high-quality clinical programs and services in medical centers, outpatient clinics, and other healthcare settings within the Network. Additionally, efforts are made to reduce duplication of functions in clinical, administrative, and operational processes. Collaboration and cooperation are also emphasized. The Secretary ensures the reduction of duplicate functions in clinical, administrative, and operational processes within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Collaboration and cooperation are emphasized for maximum effectiveness in patient care, safety, and institutional functions consolidation. The Secretary collaborates with various entities, including Veterans Benefits Administration, National Cemetery Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, and State/local agencies to support institutional functions for veterans. The Secretary collaborates with various entities to support institutional functions for veterans, including Armed Forces, Coast Guard, State/local agencies, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community organizations, faith-based organizations, and other Federal Government offices. The Secretary also ensures the development and sharing of innovations and practices within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary collaborates with various entities to support institutional functions for veterans, including Armed Forces, Coast Guard, State/local agencies, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community organizations, faith-based organizations, and other Federal Government offices. The Secretary ensures that Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels, with each network having one headquarters office co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary may employ or contract for services of up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors. The Secretary determines the location of headquarters offices for Veterans Integrated Service Networks, which are co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. The Secretary may employ or contract for services of up to 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors at each headquarters. Annual reports on employment at these headquarters are submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. During the most recent fiscal year, reports on employment at Veterans Integrated Service Networks' headquarters were submitted. The reports include the number of individuals employed at each headquarters, titles of positions at the headquarters and within the Veterans Health Administration in each network. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, assessing employment positions at headquarters and impact on the Department's budget. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting recommendations for improvement to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining Veterans Integrated Service Network 1, 2, and 3 into one network, and Veterans Integrated Service Network 4 into another. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 1, 2, and 3 will be merged into one network, as well as Networks 4 and 5, Networks 9 and 10, and Networks 11 and 12. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 10, 11, 12, 15, 17, 18, 19, and 20 will be combined into fewer networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be consolidated into fewer networks. The consolidation of Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 into a single network will involve retaining one headquarters location and eliminating others to meet specified requirements. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must eliminate headquarters locations to meet requirements, provide reemployment assistance for affected individuals, and submit an implementation plan to Congress within 180 days. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with medical centers and submit a relocation plan to Congress within 180 days. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with medical centers by either relocating them to a co-located site or renewing/entering into a new lease for the current location. If a lease is renewed or a new lease is engaged, a report must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks by renewing or entering into a new lease. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs before any lease renewal or engagement, detailing underutilized buildings in medical centers. The report to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs must include details on underutilized buildings in Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers, current lease costs, and new lease costs. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will assess finance operations, compliance activities, and overall performance within the networks. The regional support centers established by the Secretary within the Veterans Health Administration assess finance operations, compliance activities, outreach to veterans of specific operations, programs for women veterans, and programs addressing homelessness among veterans. The Secretary establishes regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess various programs for women veterans, homelessness among veterans, energy consumption, and other relevant operations and activities of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary may hire staff and contractors as needed for the regional support centers. The location of each regional support center is determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors for regional support centers. The location of each center is determined by the Secretary and may be co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. If not co-located, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs before engaging in a lease. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs before engaging in a lease for a regional support center that is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The report should include a list of underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, the number of buildings in the network, and the total underutilized square footage for each medical center in the network. The Secretary must report on underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, including the total square footage for each medical center. When establishing regional support centers, employees may be transferred from network headquarters to the new centers. The Secretary will transfer employees from network headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
